intro: Jacquinia moana, commonly known as the Hawaiian sea hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of the Pacific. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in coastal areas, often on rocky shores or sand dunes, where it thrives in saline and well-drained soils. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a rough texture, while its stems are woody and somewhat succulent. Jacquinia moana plays an important ecological role in stabilizing coastal ecosystems and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial species.
